geninfo.title: Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger
geninfo.para: The Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger (EVRT™) features actuated turbine vanes. These vanes modify the flow characteristics of exhaust gases that pass through the turbine housing. Among the advantages of the EVRT™is its ability to precisely alter the boost pressure necessary to accommodate various engine speed and load conditions. The EVRT™ also allows for lower emissions.

note.para: The EVRT™ assembly is serviceable only as a complete turbocharger assembly. When a failure is isolated to the components in the compressor/turbine housings, or control valve assemblies, the complete EVRT™ assembly (compressor/turbine housings and control valve with solenoid assembly) must be replaced.

geninfo.para: The EVRT™ is a closed loop system that uses the MAP sensor to provide input to the ECM. The ECM provides the required duty cycle to control the EVRT™ in response to engine speed and load. Continuous monitoring and evaluation of these variables allows for optimal duty cycle adjustment to match engine requirements.

The solenoid receives a pulse width modulated signal (duty cycle) that indicates the amount of time the control valve is energized. This is also referred to as the on/off time. The control valve and solenoid assembly regulate the engine oil pressure from the filter header. The control valve directs oil flow to both sides of the piston within the center housing.

The unison ring links all of the turbine vanes, and controls vane position. When the unison ring moves, each vane moves accordingly. The actuated vanes are mounted around the internal circumference of the turbine housing. Redirection of the oil to different sides of the piston will result in movement of the unison ring. This will result in the desired increase, or decrease, in manifold pressure.

svcproc.title: Diagnosing Possible EVRt™ Damage
svcproc.para: Should you suspect trouble with the EVRT™, please note that there are several diagnostic procedures that must be followed in order to determine whether or not there is a problem with the EVRT™. These steps include completing the appended Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger (EVRT™) Warranty Checklist, EGED-260, and the Performance Diagnostics side of Mechanical Diagnostics form EGED-220.

note.para: Prior approval is required from International® before turbocharger replacement under warranty. In order to be considered for warranty reimbursement, a completed Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger (EVRT™) Warranty Checklist must be attached to the EVRT™ when it is returned to International Truck and Engine Corporation.
The Electronic Variable Response Turbocharger (EVRT™) may also be referred to as the Variable Geometry Turbocharger (VGT).

svcproc.title: Fault Detection management
svcproc.para: Continuous Monitor DiagnosticThe ECM continuously monitors the duty cycle for the VGT, and compares it to preprogrammed values that are determined by the various inputs that are used.

VGT Duty Cycle Offset is the difference between duty cycle of VGT that the ECM predicts and duty cycle it actually requires to achieve a specific or desired boost in the intake system. When the ECM commands more duty cycle to achieve the desired pressures, it is referred to as VGT over duty cycle. When the ECM commands less duty cycle to achieve the desired pressures, it is referred to as VGT under duty cycle.
A Diagnostic Trouble Code (DTC) will be logged for specific over duty cycle and under duty cycle conditions.

note.para: Before diagnosing any VGT related Diagnostic Trouble Codes repair all sensor, injector, and actuator, electrical Diagnostic Trouble Codes.

svcproc.para: Follow the procedures outlined in Performance Diagnostics Form EGED-220.

randlist.title: VGT Performance can be effected by the following:

entry.para: DTC 353 indicates that the VGT over duty cycle has reached a calibrated limit. This trouble code is set when the ECM overcompensates by increasing duty cycle to the VGT in order to achieve the desired boost.
Repair all injector, sensor, and actuator, electronics
Check repair history for injector replacement
Refer to MAP circuit function and diagnostics
Refer to BAP circuit function and diagnostics
Refer to ICP circuit function and diagnostics

DTC 354 indicates that the VGT under duty cycle has reached a calibration limit. This code is set when the ECM undercompensates by decreasing the duty cycle to the VGT in order to achieve the desired boost.
Repair all injector, sensor, and actuator, electronics
Repair all injector, sensor, and actuator, electronics
Check service history for injector replacement
Refer to ICP circuit function and diagnostics
Refer to MAP circuit function and diagnostics
Refer to BAP circuit function and diagnostics

DTC 355 indicates that the turbocharger has oversped. This code is set when the ECM detects that the turbocharger has overspeed several times in a specific period of time (depending on ECM calibrations). The turbocharger speed is estimated by engine speed, boost pressure, and barometric pressure.
Repair all injector, sensor, and actuator, electronics
Refer to MAP circuit function diagnostics
Refer to BAP circuit function diagnostics

svcproc.para: Diagnostic Circuit TestThe VGT actuator is subject to the Output Circuit Check (OCC). An open or shorted control circuit can be detected by an on demand OCC test run during the Key ON Engine OFF test. An output circuit check is performed using the EST.
DTC 261: This code is set when the OCC test fails after the Key ON Engine OFF test has been run.

entry.para: VGT Circuit Operation: The VGT control valve receives ground from ECM pin number 28 at terminal B. The ECM controls the VGT by sending a pulse width modulated signal from pin number 18 to terminal A on the VGT control valve.

caution.para: After removing the connector, always check for damaged pins, corrosion, and loose terminals. Failure to do so may result in engine damage.

table.title: VGT Control Valve and Circuit Diagnostic

entry.para: Voltage Check (with regulator connector disconnected, breakout "T" installed, and ignition key ON)
If > 0.25V, ground wire is shorted to VREF or battery
Connector Checks to Ground (B-) (check with VGT connector disconnected and ignition key OFF, positive battery cable disconnected)
Resistance to chassis ground. If < 1kΩ, check for short to ground in circuit
Harness Resistance Checks (check with breakout box installed on engine harness only)
Resistance through entire VGT circuit including regulator, check with regulator connector connected to VGT
If > 5Ω VGT control wire is open
If > 5Ω VGT ground wire is open
261 = Output Circuit Check detected during Standard Test indicates high low resistance in circuit.

svcproc.title: EVRT™ Removal Procedure

caution.para: To avoid engine damage, do not operate engine without heat shield. Heat shield should not be removed for turbocharger replacement.

note.para: Special reusable locking flange nuts are used on the EVRT™. If lost or damaged, they must be replaced with the same International® type locking nuts.

svcproc.para: Remove the EVRT™ using standard procedures for International® in-line six cylinder turbochargers.

step1.para: Remove turbocharger oil supply line. Discard old o-rings. New (unused) o-rings should be used for reassembly.
Remove air inlet and exhaust outlet, clamps, and piping.
Remove EVRT™ assembly, by removing four flange nuts. Remove oil drain line at this time. Discard old o-rings.

svcproc.title: EVRT™ Installation Procedure
svcproc.para: New (unused) parts listed in the following table are necessary for installation of the EVRT™.

entry.para: O-rings for turbocharger oil drain tube
O-ring for turbocharger oil inlet tube

svcproc.para: Install the EVRT™ using standard procedures for International® in-line six cylinder turbochargers. Repeat the reverse of the procedure highlighted in the EVRT™ Removal Procedure section.

step1.para: Install EVRT™ assembly with new flange gasket, using four flange nuts. Install oil line drain at the same time. Use new (unused) o-rings. Torque nut to special torque of 52 ft-lb (71 N-m).
Install air inlet and exhaust outlet, clamps, and piping.
Before installing supply line, fill oil supply inlet cavity of the center housing with oil.
Install turbocharger oil supply line using new (unused) o-rings.

caution.para: To avoid engine damage, be careful not to twist or crimp the flexible section of the oil supply line.

entry.para: HT 530/320 hp @ 2000 rpm (1150 ft·lbf torque @ 1300 rpm)
